alt="Newberry Library" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7c3f381/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F44%2Ff9%2Fed4dafbd47b982125b70ef02ffb2%2Flibraryunions-03xx24-18-1.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/fdd097e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F44%2Ff9%2Fed4dafbd47b982125b70ef02ffb2%2Flibraryunions-03xx24-18-1.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7c3f381/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F44%2Ff9%2Fed4dafbd47b982125b70ef02ffb2%2Flibraryunions-03xx24-18-1.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>The research library will use some of the grant funds to make language-related materials more easily accessible. It comes at a time when a majority of Indigenous languages across the United States are endangered. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Now, as many tribal nations focus on revitalizing languages and teaching them again, Miron said items in the Newberry’s collection can play a critical role, especially for nations with no living speakers.</p><p>“The documents that were created that have information about these languages are crucial for linguists who can then go in and help recover what these languages sounded like and start reteaching them,” Miron said.</p><p>The Newberry collection includes Bibles and other religious texts created by missionaries who were attempting to assimilate tribal members by translating those works to Indigenous languages. Among the other linguistic items are boarding school materials that were translated into Dakota.</p><p>“All of these materials provide an important connection to the past and an important connection to ancestors,” Miron said. “I have seen people in the collection weep upon seeing something that is related to their family, or is related to their community that they've never seen before.”</p><p>Tribal nations can also request digitization of other parts of the collection.</p><p>The Mellon funds will also be used to hire three additional staff members, including a second dedicated librarian for the Indigenous collection. Additionally, the dollars will go toward fellowships for people who work for tribal nations, travel for tribal members to visit the collection and for librarians to visit tribal nations. Some grant funds are intended, too, for compensation for tribal members who help the library review items in the collection and for in-depth projects with partner tribal nations.</p><p>In total, Newberry says, more than half the funds will go directly to tribal nations.</p><p>“We fundamentally believe that tribal nations are the best representatives of their own history,” said Miron, adding that the library is also open to repatriating items in its collection.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-530000" name="image-530000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/72632ec/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1800x1010+0+226/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F4a%2F54%2F807dc9ad43ac8426afb9fbd38151%2F3-schoolcraft-ayer-e77-s41-plt-60-o3-1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1cc879c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1800x1010+0+226/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F4a%2F54%2F807dc9ad43ac8426afb9fbd38151%2F3-schoolcraft-ayer-e77-s41-plt-60-o3-1.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1b95896/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1800x1010+0+226/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F4a%2F54%2F807dc9ad43ac8426afb9fbd38151%2F3-schoolcraft-ayer-e77-s41-plt-60-o3-1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Symbolic Petition of the Cippewa Chiefs" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1b95896/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1800x1010+0+226/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F4a%2F54%2F807dc9ad43ac8426afb9fbd38151%2F3-schoolcraft-ayer-e77-s41-plt-60-o3-1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/994381e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1800x1010+0+226/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F4a%2F54%2F807dc9ad43ac8426afb9fbd38151%2F3-schoolcraft-ayer-e77-s41-plt-60-o3-1.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1b95896/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1800x1010+0+226/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F4a%2F54%2F807dc9ad43ac8426afb9fbd38151%2F3-schoolcraft-ayer-e77-s41-plt-60-o3-1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>This image, part of Newberry’s collection, represents the clans of the ogimaag (chiefs) of the Lake Superior bands of Ojibwe. The clans are shown united at a time when they were petitioning the US government to revise treaty boundaries set in 1842. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Courtesy of Newberry Library</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The Indigenous collection at the library originated with a donation in 1911 from the wealthy businessman Edward E. Ayer, whom Miron said was an avid collector of books, manuscripts, artwork and publications about different tribal nations. Ayer also endowed the collection, and that has allowed the Newberry to grow the collection over the years and dedicate a librarian to it.</p><p>In recent years, Miron said, the approach to expanding this collection has shifted to “prioritizing materials created by Native people rather than just materials about Native people.”</p><p>The latest round of Mellon funding is an extension of a previous planning grant, which the museum received in 2020. The planning process resulted in the “<a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/curious-city/2024/11/21/indigenous-chicago-project-shows-the-city-has-always-been-a-native-place" target="_blank" ><u>Indigenous Chicago</u></a>” project, which looks to provide information and resources on Chicago’s historic and modern-day Indigenous communities. It includes interactive online maps that reinterpret Chicago’s history from Native American perspectives.</p><p>The project comes amid other recent local efforts to better recognize Indigenous people and their culture. A new partnership between the American Indian Center of Chicago and the Forest Preserve of Kane County led to the introduction of <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/environment/2026/01/23/burlington-prairie-bison-herd-kane-county-illinois-native-americans" target="_blank" ><u>a new bison herd</u></a>, bringing the animals to the local tallgrass prairie for the first time in 200 years. The center will steward the herd.</p><p>In her role at the library, Miron said she is conscious of the way institutions like Newberry have contributed to pain inflicted upon Indigenous communities. “As an institution that has benefited from colonialism, I really see it as our job to try to undo some of that harm and to really return control to tribal nations,” Miron said.</p><p>The grant work is now underway and will continue through December 2030.</p><p><i>Courtney Kueppers is an arts and culture reporter at WBEZ. </i></p>
entries.author: Courtney Kueppers | WBEZ

entries.title: Chicago surgeon who oversaw heart operation in Alaska where patient died could now lose Illinois license
entries.summary: <p>With his medical license temporarily suspended in Illinois since 2023 following the death of a heart patient in Alaska, a Chicago surgeon is facing a disciplinary proceeding next month that could help determine whether he will ever practice medicine here again.</p><p>Once licensed in multiple states, Dr. Cosmin Dobrescu was issued a “physician temporary permit” in Alaska in September 2022 so he could serve in a “locum tenens” role — essentially working as a cardiothoracic surgeon on an as-needed basis at Alaska Regional Hospital in Anchorage.</p><p>In December 2022, Dobrescu operated on a 73-year-old man in poor health “to replace a stenotic aortic valve and revascularize the coronary arteries,” according to public records that say a “cascade of problems developed during the surgery” and the patient ended up “dying on the table.”</p><p>Two other doctors subsequently filed a complaint against Dobrescu, alleging they witnessed “unsafe care” during the 13-hour operation and that “he was a threat to the health and welfare of the public,” according to a February 2023 affidavit from an investigator for Alaska’s professional regulatory agency.</p><p>The affidavit “supported” a request by the agency to suspend Dobrescu’s license, which Alaska’s medical board acted on days later, concluding he “poses a clear and immediate danger to the public health and safety if he continues to practice medicine.”</p><p>Within days, the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation, the arm of state government that regulates doctors in Illinois, temporarily suspended his Illinois license based on Alaska’s decision.</p><p>Illinois law allows regulators to “revoke, suspend, place on probation, reprimand, refuse to issue or renew, or take any other disciplinary or non-disciplinary action” on the basis of “adverse action taken by another state or jurisdiction.”</p><p>Last year, Alaska revoked his medical license, and New York followed suit.</p><p>Pointing to those decisions, Illinois regulators filed a new complaint calling for Dobrescu’s license to be “suspended, revoked, or otherwise disciplined.”</p><p>An administrative trial was recently set for March 31 after which a judge will issue findings and a disciplinary recommendation to the Illinois State Medical Board, whose members are appointed by the governor.</p><p>The medical board can adopt the conclusions or come to its own. Either way, the matter lands with a top administrator at the state’s financial and professional regulation department for a final decision.</p><p>Regulators don’t need to prove the allegations against Dobrescu, only that another jurisdiction took “adverse action” against him.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-d50000" name="image-d50000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/dea8a3d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1328x745+0+357/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F9c%2Fe6%2Fe973991c42c3864343f72857ce13%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-18-at-11-36-22-am.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/9a80db6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1328x745+0+357/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F9c%2Fe6%2Fe973991c42c3864343f72857ce13%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-18-at-11-36-22-am.png width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1c5fc1d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1328x745+0+357/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F9c%2Fe6%2Fe973991c42c3864343f72857ce13%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-18-at-11-36-22-am.png" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Part of the complaint filed by Illinois regulators against Dr. Cosmin Dobrescu." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1c5fc1d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1328x745+0+357/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F9c%2Fe6%2Fe973991c42c3864343f72857ce13%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-18-at-11-36-22-am.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7d4ecad/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1328x745+0+357/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F9c%2Fe6%2Fe973991c42c3864343f72857ce13%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-18-at-11-36-22-am.png 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1c5fc1d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1328x745+0+357/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F9c%2Fe6%2Fe973991c42c3864343f72857ce13%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-18-at-11-36-22-am.png" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Part of the complaint filed by Illinois regulators against Dr. Cosmin Dobrescu.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>A graduate of Northwestern University and raised in Munster, Indiana, Dobrescu has portrayed the central allegations against him in Alaska as “false,” saying the investigator’s affidavit was rife with misinformation and laid the mistakes of others on him.</p><p>One of the complaining doctors alleged that Dobrescu “used a nonstandard strategy of transecting the aorta entirely to gain access to the aortic valve, which led to significant bleeding that Dr. Dobrescu was unable to remedy,” according to the affidavit.</p><p>When Dobrescu “was confronted with the severe bleeding from his suture lines,” he persisted “in a failing strategy of adding stitches... and refused to perform hypothermic circulatory arrest despite repeated recommendations to do so,” according to the affidavit.</p><p>The complaining doctor said that “in efforts to repair the bleeding that Dr. Dobrescu had caused, Dr. Dobrescu inadvertently perforated the pulmonary artery,” the affidavit said.</p><p>Dobrescu has, in turn, pointed blame for the outcome of the surgery on one of the complaining doctors, an anesthesiologist, who Dobrescu alleged “did not replace blood products correctly” as the patient bled out, records show.</p><p>The anesthesiologist has insisted he acted properly, and an administrative law judge in Alaska concluded in 2025 that “the evidence is too ambiguous to make a clear finding on whether there were departures from the standard of care in the final administration of blood products,” records show.</p><p>The judge also seemed to find no major fault in how Dobrescu performed the surgery, writing: “Fundamentally, the demonstrated problem with this surgery is not its execution, but instead that it probably should not have been occurring in the first place.”</p><p>The judge hammered Dobrescu for forging ahead with an operation not deemed urgent.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-dc0000" name="image-dc0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/95ef2f5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1166x654+0+341/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F2f%2Fed%2F49382e0b435da8b27cac92954b17%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-18-at-11-47-29-am.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2de0bcb/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1166x654+0+341/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F2f%2Fed%2F49382e0b435da8b27cac92954b17%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-18-at-11-47-29-am.png 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/76e5059/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1166x654+0+341/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F2f%2Fed%2F49382e0b435da8b27cac92954b17%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-18-at-11-47-29-am.png" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Part of the findings of an administrative law judge in Alaska on Dr. Cosmin Dobrescu." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/76e5059/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1166x654+0+341/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F2f%2Fed%2F49382e0b435da8b27cac92954b17%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-18-at-11-47-29-am.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0cf6124/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1166x654+0+341/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F2f%2Fed%2F49382e0b435da8b27cac92954b17%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-18-at-11-47-29-am.png 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/76e5059/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1166x654+0+341/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F2f%2Fed%2F49382e0b435da8b27cac92954b17%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-18-at-11-47-29-am.png" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Part of the findings of an administrative law judge in Alaska on Dr. Cosmin Dobrescu.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Dobrescu’s “recommendation on December 5 to go to surgery on December 7 overlooked important risk factors” — including “poor” diabetes control in the patient — “as did his downstream failure to reconsider up to the hour of surgery,” the judge wrote.</p><p>“The decision-making process fell below the standard of care.”</p><p>The judge wrote that the patient’s death “was substantially related to the substandard pre-operative risk evaluation,” and that after “losing a patient in this manner, the licensee” — Dobrescu — “exhibited deeply irresponsible behavior by failing to provide an operative report.”</p><p>Dobrescu said he was “put in an impossible position” because his lawyer advised not to immediately release that report due to concerns it would be used to help prosecute him for negligent homicide, though a criminal case never materialized.</p><p>An autopsy could have provided more clarity over the man’s death, but for reasons still unclear one wasn’t conducted initially and wasn’t possible later because the patient had been cremated, records show.</p><p>The judge’s ruling also found regulators had “proven” that Dobrescu “obtained licensure in Alaska by fraud” by failing to reveal on his paperwork that he “was under active investigation in Virginia” administratively “for incompetence.”</p><p>Dobrescu argued that a consultant he’d hired to complete the application advised that the Virginia investigation — which examined his personal and professional conduct in a number of states — didn’t need to be disclosed.</p><p>The Alaska patient’s daughter testified at Alaska’s administrative hearing that she was there when her father was wheeled into surgery, records show.</p><p>“I hugged him, and I kissed him, and I told him to do good,” she said.</p><p>“And he said, ‘Don't tell me. Tell them to do good.’”</p>
entries.author: Robert Herguth

entries.title: Operation Midway Blitz fallout lingers in Latino neighborhoods
entries.summary: <p>The ground shifted under Chicago last fall. What's normal in the city's majority-Latino communities today isn't what it was before Operation Midway Blitz.</p><p>The Southeast Side, long defined by steel mills and working-class communities, was one of the first places Mexicans came to Chicago more than a century ago. On the Lower West Side, Pilsen stands out for its colorful murals, rich arts and culinary scene and lively Mexican American culture. Farther southwest, Little Village, also known as La Villita, has a vibrant commercial corridor and community celebrations like the Mexican Independence Day parade that are among the oldest and largest in the Midwest.</p><p>These neighborhoods carved separate paths to becoming majority-Latino and cultural centers for Mexican communities in Chicago. But they shared a common experience last fall: the Trump administration's Operation Midway Blitz.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/live/2025/09/16/cbp-raids-ice-chicago-elgin-operation-at-large" >The immigration enforcement campaign began Sept. 16,</a> Mexican Independence Day.</p><p>Federal officials said the operation targeted violent criminals without legal status, though <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/03/28/tren-de-aragua-venezuela-gang-trump-tom-homan-terrorism-violence-crime-chicago-colombia-honduras-ecuador-nicolas-maduro-salvador" >this proved largely untrue</a>. As enforcement increased, fear spread across Chicago and its suburbs. Latino and immigrant-majority neighborhoods, including Pilsen, Little Village and the Southeast Side, went on high alert.</p><p>These communities developed their Latino identities over generations, shaped by migration, labor and displacement. Trump’s targeted immigration operations created a shared moment in their histories — a moment filled with fear, uncertainty and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/small-business/2026/02/13/shop-local-campaign-brighton-park-immigration-raids-local-businesses" >community pride</a>.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="top" name="top"></a> </div> </div><p></p><h3>A Latino identity developed over more than century</h3><h4>Southeast Side </h4><p>Chicago’s Mexican American population first took root in the early 1900s. Many arrived in 1919, when they were recruited during a national steel mill strike. These communities became part of the backbone of heavily industrial South Chicago and the East Side, creating an identity that endures today.</p><p>In 1923, the community established Our Lady of Guadalupe Church, the first Mexican American parish in the city.</p><p>As of 2023, Latinos on the East Side and South Chicago made up half of the neighborhoods’ 52,000 residents, according to the Chicago Metropolitan Agency for Planning. The East Side alone is nearly 90% Latino.</p><p><b>Stories from South Chicago and the Southeast Side</b>: <a class="Link" href="#sc-masa" >Cecy’s Molino de Masa</a> | <a class="Link" href="#sc-maria" >Maria</a> | <a class="Link" href="#ses-natg" >Illinois National Guard member</a> | <a class="Link" href="#sc-pedraza" >Corina Pedraza</a> | <a class="Link" href="#ses-bautista" >Olga Sept. 15, 1957.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Southeast Chicago Historical Society</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h4>Pilsen</h4><p>Before Pilsen became known for its Mexican and Mexican American identity — its streets lined with colorful murals, Mexican stores and restaurants — the neighborhood was home to waves of European immigrants. Named after Plzeň in what is now the Czech Republic, Pilsen began to change in the mid-20th century as Mexican and Puerto Rican families moved in, many displaced from the Near West Side by expressway construction and the expansion of the University of Illinois Chicago campus.</p><p>By the 1960s, Pilsen had become predominantly Latino, shaped by social activism, civic engagement and artistic expression. Today, Pilsen is 68% Latino and Hispanic, according to U.S. Census data. In recent years, rising housing costs and new development have raised concerns about gentrification and the displacement of longtime residents.</p><p><b>Stories from Pilsen and the Southwest Side</b>: class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Mexican students protest at the Froebel Branch of Harrison High School at 2021 W. 21st St. in Chicago, May 5, 1973. Students and families in Pilsen called for a new high school to be built that would better cater to the area’s Spanish-speaking students. This plan was met with resistance from the Chicago Board of Education.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Sun-Times file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h4>Little Village</h4><p>Located in South Lawndale, Little Village was once known as “Czech California,” reflecting its strong Czech, Slovak and other Eastern European communities and their businesses along 26th Street.</p><p>In the mid-1960s, as Black people moved to neighboring North Lawndale, the white business owners and leaders of South Lawndale began calling that area “Little Village” to highlight the European ethnic community and differentiate it from North Lawndale, according to a city report on the neighborhood’s history. But Little Village’s white residents still moved to the suburbs, leaving room for Mexican families, many of whom were pushed west from Pilsen.</p><p>By 1980, Latinos made up nearly half of Little Village’s population, with Mexicans as the dominant group. In 1990, the Mexican government donated the Little Village arch, cementing the neighborhood's identity. It reads “Bienvenidos a Little Village.”</p><p>The neighborhood was proud of its roots. Many began to call Little Village the “Mexico of the Midwest.” The latest U.S. Census data shows South Lawndale, still the area’s official name, is 81% Latino and Hispanic.</p><p>The Pilsen and Little Village corridor now has the largest concentration of Latinos in the Midwest. Little Village’s 26th Street commercial corridor generates millions in annual revenue and is the city's second highest tax-generating district, after the Magnificent Mile.</p><p><b>Stories from Little Village/La Villita</b>: <a class="Link" href="#lv-viento" >Viento, the running club</a> | <a class="Link" href="#lv-morenos" >Moreno’s Liquors</a></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>In 1983, Rudy Lozano, a Mexican-American community activist who was instrumental in campaigning for the election of Harold Washington as mayor, was murdered in his home following Washington’s victory. The funeral service was at St. Pius Catholic Church, 1919 S. Ashland Ave., and the procession went down 26th Street in Pilsen. Washington attended the funeral.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Sun-Times file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3>Operation Midway Blitz’s disruption of communities</h3><p>The feds’ targeting of Latino and immigrant-majority neighborhoods wasn’t surprising, but the agents’ aggression, detention of nonviolent immigrants and blatant contempt for people of color became flash points.</p><p>Early during Operation Midway Blitz, in September, Border Patrol Cmdr. Gregory Bovino told a WBEZ reporter that some people are arrested based partly <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/09/28/ice-agents-spotted-downtown-on-michigan-avenue-along-chicago-river" >on “how they look.”</a></p><p>Toward the end of the operation, on Nov. 10, dozens of Border Patrol agents posed Downtown in front of The Bean. As they prepared to take the picture, an agent reportedly said, “Everyone say ‘Little Village!” According to media reports, the agents shouted back “Little Village!”</p><p>In between, federal agents <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/11/05/daycare-teacher-taken-by-ice-north-side-immigration" >disrupted daily life</a>, particularly in places like Little Village, Pilsen and the Southeast Side. Immigrants and other Chicagoans feared detention while walking outside, waiting for the bus or taking children to school.</p><p>In some neighborhoods, the streets were empty. <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/11/07/chicago-business-civic-leaders-ice-economy" >Business owners saw drastic declines in sales.</a> Some feared having to close. Community events and parades were canceled.</p><p>Neighborhoods known for their vibrancy and close-knit community life were quiet.</p><p>Families feared separation, and parents worried about the long-term impact on their children.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/11/06/judge-sara-ellis-operation-midway-blitz-tear-gas-deportation-campaign" >Critics of the immigration operations pointed to violent tactics</a>, performative operations and unconstitutional detentions. Supporters said the federal government was targeting violent and dangerous immigrants.</p><p>According to U.S. Department of Justice documents, 97% of those detained during Operation Midway Blitz had no criminal records.</p><p>The Trump administration continued to push the narrative that it was taking murders and rapists off the streets.</p><p>After the agents posed at The Bean, they began leaving Chicago. The federal influx of some 300 agents for Operation Midway Blitz ended. But ICE enforcement — U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement — continues. And while that enforcement has remained at pre-Blitz levels, the communities the feds swarmed are changed. Here’s what’s different, according to people who live there.</p><h3>The aftereffects</h3><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="lv-viento" [timezone]</template> <span data-date> </span> </bsp-timestamp><span class="dot"></span></div> <div class="PagePromo-author"> <span>By </span><strong><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/wbez-staff" >WBEZ Staff </a></strong> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div><p>Before Operation Midway Blitz, the captains and runners of Viento, the Little Village run club, would message each other only to cancel a run. Now they message to check if there have been sightings of federal agents and then decide when they’ll run and their route.</p><p>“I'm usually checking in, ‘How are you all personally?’ but also, ‘What do you think about running today? What's something that we should keep an eye on?’” says Jess Vergara, 37, who was part of the group that created the club 13 years ago. “So we are prepared when things kind of pop up.”</p><p>The club has a new rule: No one can run by themselves. Vergara says runners will slow down or run back to make sure no one is too far behind.</p><p>Viento means "wind" in Spanish. The club is mostly Latino and runs three times a week, meeting at 26th Street and South Central Park Avenue, as they have for 13 years.</p><p>Residents recognize them. Business owners wave as they pass, and members often gather after runs at restaurants for coffee.</p><p>Federal immigration agents arrived in September, about a month before the Chicago Marathon. For many runners, not running wasn’t an option after weeks of training.</p><p>Vergara and the other captains wanted to keep the runners safe. They mapped out routes and water stops; they identified safe havens in case agents targeted them. Members provided emergency contacts in case any runners were detained. The club held Know Your Rights training for runners and their families.</p><p>Now, Vergara says, they are trying to keep the runners motivated, but they are also preparing, in case the feds come back.</p><p>“We are constantly checking the news, what other organizations are doing in La Villita and around Chicago,” she says. “We keep in touch with the rapid response teams and see what they're saying.”</p><p>“It's such a different feeling. It's this constant vigilance and heightened anxiety."</p><p><a class="Link" href="#lv-top" ><i>Return to top</i></a></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a We’re in this together."</a> </div> <button class="AudioPlayerController"> <bsp-player-controller data-srcpath="https://podcast-stream.wbez.org/recast/wbez-features/20260219195042-BlitzBusiness_260225_aga_web.mp3" data-playdata='[{"ctaUrl": "https://chicago.suntimes.com/2026/02/19/morenos-liquors-todo-juntos-were-in-this-together","ctaButtonText": "Read More","programName": "Moreno's Liquors: "Todo juntos. We’re in this together."","streamUrl": "https://podcast-stream.wbez.org/recast/wbez-features/20260219195042-BlitzBusiness_260225_aga_web.mp3","streamId": "https://podcast-stream.wbez.org/recast/wbez-features/20260219195042-BlitzBusiness_260225_aga_web.mp3","playable": true}]'> <template data-bsp-item-description="https://podcast-stream.wbez.org/recast/wbez-features/20260219195042-BlitzBusiness_260225_aga_web.mp3"> </template> <div class="AudioPlayerController-playPauseIcons"> <svg class="AudioPlayerController-IconPlay"> <use xlink:href="#play-icon" /></svg> <svg class="AudioPlayerController-IconPause"><use xlink:href="#pause" /></svg> </div> Listen </bsp-player-controller> </button> <div class="PagePromo-byline"><div class="PagePromo-date"> <bsp-timestamp data-timestamp=1771553665000 data-promo="true"> <template data-date-tpl>[month] [day], [year], [hour]:[minute][ampm] [timezone]</template> <span data-date> </span> </bsp-timestamp><span class="dot"></span></div> <div class="PagePromo-author"> <span>By </span><strong><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/wbez-staff" >WBEZ Staff </a></strong> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div><p>Sales declined sharply at Moreno’s Liquors during federal immigration operations. Customers have started to return, “but people have this uneasiness,” store owner Mike Moreno Jr. says.</p><p>They send him messages asking if he can verify the area is clear of immigration agents before they go out.</p><p>“Before immigration came in, if somebody saw a drone, no one thought anything of it," Moreno says. "If somebody saw a helicopter flying over, they thought, 'OK, it's the news checking traffic or Chicago Police Department doing something.' Now people are scared."</p><p>Moreno, 34, is a third-generation entrepreneur. He grew up in Archer Heights. His grandfather immigrated to the United States in the 1960s, and his family later moved to Little Village, where they were among the first Mexican families in the neighborhood. In 1977, his father opened Moreno’s Liquors, which became one of the first Latino-owned liquor stores in Illinois. In 2019, Moreno expanded the business with Osito’s Tap, a speakeasy next door.</p><p>With the presence of federal agents last fall, people stayed inside, Moreno says. Sales dropped 20% at first, as much as 60% at one point, and leveled off at a 40% drop for two months.</p><p>He says his business hasn’t fully recovered, and perhaps it won’t any time soon.</p><p>“It's the perfect storm. You've got inflation that's at an all-time high, you have tariffs that are exasperating that. Layoffs are happening across the board,” Moreno says. “You put all of those together, and the last thing you need is for people to be scared to even go out and shop.”</p><p>“No one should be treated like that. It’s disrespectful and inhumane,” he says.</p><p>Moreno says his family taught him the importance of civic engagement and advocacy. His father helped establish the Little Village Chamber of Commerce and worked with community leaders to build the neighborhood’s iconic arch.</p><p>Even though there was fear in the fall, Moreno says, residents came together, and the moment could unite Latinos across communities.</p><p>“To see people helping each other, bringing food to an abuelita who was afraid to go out or warning neighbors about threats, that was inspiring,” he says.</p><p>“We won’t give up,” he adds. “Todo juntos. We’re in this together.”</p><p><a class="Link" href="#lv-top" ><i>Return to top</i></a></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="sc-masa" [timezone]</template> <span data-date> </span> </bsp-timestamp><span class="dot"></span></div> <div class="PagePromo-author"> <span>By </span><strong><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/wbez-staff" >WBEZ Staff </a></strong> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div><p>Since 1986, Cecilia “Cecy” Villarruel has been producing masa in South Chicago. She uses a molino, a machine that grinds up corn, water and other ingredients to make the dough used in Mexican favorites like tamales.</p><p>Instead of celebrating 40 years in business this year, Villarruel is worrying about her friends, family, employees and the neighborhood overall.</p><p>After ICE and Border Patrol began targeting South Chicago and the adjacent Southeast Side neighborhoods last fall, Villarruel noticed a change, especially around Thanksgiving and Christmas, typically a busy time.</p><p>“It was slow. The people were afraid to stand in line,” she says in her native Spanish.</p><p>Her son, Saul Villarruel, who handles the finances for the business, says sales have dramatically decreased since the holidays.</p><p>Even now, “People are terrorized to go out,” Cecy Villarruel says. “I’m not afraid to go, but I’m afraid for my employees.”</p><p>Villarruel, a naturalized American citizen, says one worker didn't want to go out for three or four months, and some of her workers still are afraid to go outside and come to work.</p><p>“We would deliver food to their homes. A lot of them would send their grandkids, and we would also try to take the products to their home,” Villarruel says.</p><p>Saul Villarruel says when workers don’t show up, it’s up to other family members to pick up the slack for the small staff. “It’s still a problem,” he says.</p><p>In a community of African and Latino immigrants, he sees "people looking over their shoulder,” he says. “Some people are afraid of getting stopped for just being Latino.”</p><p>Even though he’s American-born and a citizen, Saul Villarruel worries about his own safety.</p><p>“By looking at me, nobody ever assumes that I'm Mexican. In that sense, I'm kind of protected. But I'm not. My parents are literally immigrants. A lot of people I know are from immigrants,” he says. “These are people I've worked with, people I've grown up with, people who have taken care of me. I feel an obligation, a responsibility to them.”</p><p><a class="Link" href="#top" ><i>Return to top</i></a></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Maria stands for a photo in South Chicago, Friday, Feb. 13, 2026.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Maria, a 46-year-old mother of four, describes a feeling of panic and being trapped in her South Chicago home.</p><p>She goes to her job at a business in the surrounding area, but her family limits its other activities.</p><p>“We don’t go to events. We stopped going to the library, doctor’s appointments. It’s changed our lives 100%,” says Maria, who asked that her last name be withheld because she fears getting deported. “At nighttime, you can’t fall asleep. You’re afraid for them to knock on the door. You don’t know what time of day they are going to come. They could break your windows.”</p><p>Maria arrived five years ago from the Mexican border town Reynosa.</p><p>“It was great. We had a lot of fun. Life was good,” she says in her native Spanish.</p><p>But that’s changed. Maria says she is scared to go out for groceries and to take her children to school.</p><p>“My 13-year-old daughter is under a lot of stress right now, and her hair is falling out,” she says. "It's snowed, and we haven't been able to go play in the snow. … They have even had to miss things like football practice, boxing training and other everyday activities they were used to doing.”</p><p>Maria has to talk bluntly to her children so they are prepared for what could happen.</p><p>“We plan on staying here," she says. "If God allows us to stay here, we’ll stay here, unless they come for us and we’ll have to return to Mexico. We would have to start over, because our lives are here."</p><p><a class="Link" href="#top" ><i>Return to top</i></a></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/wbez-staff" >WBEZ Staff </a></strong> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div><p>Joining the National Guard seemed like a good idea to a 20-year-old Southeast Side resident.</p><p>While she was born in the United States, her mother and siblings are undocumented.</p><p>She says she joined the Guard hoping to ease the path for her relatives to be naturalized.</p><p>“I wanted to give them a better future,” she says, asking that she not be identified because she fears reprisals for talking to the media.</p><p>The threat of President Donald Trump sending the National Guard into Chicago’s streets has diminished since the fall, but it still hangs over Guard members who in some cases would have to patrol their own neighborhoods.</p><p>“I won't feel good with that at all,” the Southeast Side woman says. “I know if I go and I have to detain people, I will be crying because I can’t control myself. It’s people that came for a better life and better opportunities and give a better future for the kids.”</p><p>She says all her friends in the guard feel conflicted.</p><p>“Most of the people that I work with are Hispanic,” she says. “They are really sad about the things, and they see how this government is just messed up and everything, but like, there's nothing they really can do about anything.”</p><p><a class="Link" href="#top" ><i>Return to top</i></a></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="sc-pedraza" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/wbez-staff" >WBEZ Staff </a></strong> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div><p>When ICE arrived in South Chicago last year, some people were caught off guard, Corina Pedraza says.</p><p>“The feeling was that we are so secluded or far away from Little Village, from Back of the Yards, they won't come here. That all got shattered in October. They found the East Side,” says Pedraza, 51, a member of both the Southwest and Southeast Side Rapid Response teams, community groups that mobilize when residents report sightings of ICE or federal agents.</p><p>“I think the community at large was just shocked to see the level of violence and the aggressive behavior,” she says. “There were teenagers that were slammed to the ground right at the busiest corner of the East Side, 106th and Ewing. They were going after anybody and everybody who has dark skin.”</p><p>Now, Pedraza says people here are living their lives more cautiously. ICE encounters are down, but community members fear a return in March and residents are being cautious.</p><p>“People are still going onto social media and saying, ‘I saw some dark SUVs. I saw an SUV with dark tinted windows. Can someone check?’” Pedraza says. “I don't think that has gone away. I think that people are definitely keeping eyes and ears open, because we know that agents have not left the area.”</p><p>Pedraza’s family arrived in South Chicago in the 1960s. Her father taught at several local institutions before opening a small business of his own, and her mother worked long hours at Jay’s Potato Chips. Like many families there, Pedraza says, “They helped build the neighborhood brick by brick, shift by shift.”</p><p>In November 2024, to win the presidential election, Trump gained ground with Latino voters. Many, even in the Southeast Side and South Chicago area, support him and his policies, Pedraza said.</p><p>That’s causing a divide in the community, she says.</p><p>“There’s definitely people who feel like 'I'm an American citizen, I have nothing to hide. It’s not a big deal to just show them your ID,'” Pedraza says. “But there are other people who feel that it is a big deal. Why can I not walk in my neighborhood without feeling like I have to prove to someone that I am a citizen? I thought we were living in the United States.”</p><p><a class="Link" href="#top" ><i>Return to top</i></a></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/wbez-staff" >WBEZ Staff </a></strong> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div><p>Olga Bautista speaks proudly about the Southeast Side, her only home for all her 47 years.</p><p>“This community is families from all over the world,” she says. “Eastern European families, Mexican families, people from Latin America. Black sharecroppers from the South came up to work in the steel mills. There’s such a rich mix of cultures here.”</p><p>Nestled along Lake Michigan, the area is known for Calumet and Steelworkers parks, where families gather, children play soccer and generations have built memories. Bautista recalls walking to the lake in minutes, attending day camp and later watching her own child train as a lifeguard there.</p><p>Our Lady of Guadalupe Parish, where she and her children were baptized, is among the oldest Mexican-American Catholic churches in the Midwest.</p><p>But the sense of safety and community has been shaken.</p><p>“We have seen a huge drop in people on the streets, shopping in the commercial corridors,” says Bautista, a member of the Chicago Board of Education. “Folks are not going to their doctor's appointments. Children are not going to school. It is definitely impacting the way that we socialize, the way that we are in community with each other. The businesses here are taking a big hit.”</p><p>The U.S. Coast Guard facility near Calumet Park had felt approachable, with Coast Guard members interacting with families, hosting Halloween trick-or-treating and sitting at picnic tables. Security and fencing increased and it became more “militarized,” Bautista says.</p><p>She and other residents believe the area has been used as a staging ground for immigration enforcement operations. Those operations have had a chilling effect across the neighborhood, she says.</p><p>“I'm still getting notices that families have been abducted just this week. They are being kidnapped," Bautista says. "They're not asking for information. They just take these folks. They pull them out of their cars, out of their houses. It's very violent. It's very traumatizing to them and to their families and this whole community — from the stories of how people are being abducted to the visual images on TV.”</p><p><a class="Link" href="#top" ><i>Return to top</i></a></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="sw-progresando" name="sw-progresando"></a> </div> </div><p></p><h4>Southwest data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7d737ed/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+433/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcb%2F0a%2F5dfb817a45e6bd8c968258f595aa%2Fblitzeffect-260215-004.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Latinos Progresando CEO Luis Gutierrez leads a community resource meeting at Maria Saucedo Scholastic Academy in Little Village in February.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Latinos Progresando, an organization that supports immigrant communities like Pilsen and Little Village, is dealing with the fallout from Operation Midway Blitz.</p><p>Community members want answers, says Luis Gutierrez, who founded the organization 28 years ago.</p><p>Many ask for help navigating the immigration system and locating family members who have been detained. Staff members spend hours trying to determine where detainees are being held. Residents come in worried about their loved one not having their medicine or any means to communicate with them.</p><p>“They come in every day looking for help,” says Gutierrez, 53, who spent the holiday season delivering groceries, essential household goods and gifts. He and his staff visited families who were too scared to leave their homes for fear of being detained or deported.</p><p>The work has taken a toll on nonprofit and advocacy workers, he says: “You’re constantly answering phone calls, emails and texts, trying to provide some sort of information.”</p><p>He says advocates sounded the alarm early last year, asking for support, especially after they saw what happened in Los Angeles in the summer, but few outside the Latino community initially responded.</p><p>“Toward the end of last year, suddenly the city woke up,” Gutierrez says. “You saw people across communities standing up and saying, ‘This isn’t right.’”</p><p>The son of Mexican immigrants, Gutierrez, who grew up in Little Village, says he knows firsthand about fear and resilience.</p><p>Possible detention by federal immigration officials has caused widespread anxiety and trauma, building a need for mental health services, he says. “Our community really has been in emergency response mode since COVID started, and we have not stopped.”</p><p>“I’m working with principals and we’re talking about kids walking to school by themselves,” Gutierrez says. “We’re talking about a lack of participation in programs and even in local school councils.”</p><p>“It’s sad,” he says. “But when I talk to community residents and see [them] navigating the system, talking to their kids, preparing their families, there’s so much strength and beauty in how they stand up during this time.”</p><p>Gutierrez says residents believe immigration agents will return, but they feel more prepared.</p><p>“Other communities are standing up and protesting, and so we are going to continue the work, and whatever comes, we're going to deal with it.”</p><p><a class="Link" href="#pilsen-top" ><i>Return to top</i></a></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="pils-alejandra" name="pils-alejandra"></a> </div> </div><p></p><h4>Pilsen: data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Alejandra at the offices of Kids First Chicago in the Loop, Wednesday, Jan. 21, 2026.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Alejandra, an immigrant mother of three, is an active parent. For years, she’s enrolled her kids in after-school activities and volunteered with a parent support group.</p><p>“My biggest hope is that all my children grow up to be good people and become upstanding members of society,” she says. “It’s up to us as parents to lead them down the right path.”</p><p>Like many immigrants from Mexico, Alejandra says she came to the United States 20 years ago looking for a better life and more opportunities for her future children. She and her husband wanted to raise their children in Pilsen.</p><p>But now, after living through the fall surge of federal immigration enforcement, she is rethinking her community involvement.</p><p>She said she’s tentatively allowed her children — one in high school and two in elementary school — to resume extracurricular activities like soccer and theater club that they had stopped doing in the fall.</p><p>But she says that may change in the coming months.</p><p>“We are still a little scared. I worry that people who agree with this administration behave badly or aggressively towards our community. I don’t want my kids to see any of that,” she says.</p><p>Alejandra says Pilsen is usually calm and close-knit, but that the sense of safety is gone.</p><p>“Our lives have changed. You can feel it, [our community has] distrust. There are people that only see the color of our skin and identify us as enemies,” she says. “They don’t know how many years we have lived here and how we have been paying taxes and not receiving any benefits. I feel people think we are taking things from them, but that’s not the case.”</p><p>Alejandra says her family knows people who have had encounters with immigration agents, including one family whose father was arrested and detained.</p><p>“This shouldn’t be happening,” she says.</p><p>She says fear has reshaped everything. “People aren’t as chatty as they used to be. You notice people are gone, like the tamale vendor who used to be on the corner.”</p><p>Despite her fear, she remains optimistic about her children’s future.</p><p>“I tell my children not to be ashamed,” she says. “Never turn your back on your community.”</p><p><a class="Link" href="#pilsen-top" ><i>Return to top</i></a></p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> entries.author: Michael Puente

entries.title: Draft analyst: Bears in 'good spot' to take LT or DE with Pick 25
entries.summary: <p>The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> need a left tackle and a defensive end.</p><p></p><p>This is a good year, then, to draft 25<sup>th</sup> overall.</p><p></p><p>“There are some years where your need and where you’re picking and you’re like, ‘Oh, crap, we better move one way or the other,’” NFL Network draft analyst Daniel Jeremiah said Thursday. “I think they can just sit right where they are and see how it falls.”</p><p></p><p>The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears-stadium/2026/02/19/chicago-bears-stadium-hammond-indiana-move" target="_blank" >Bears</a> haven’t picked this late in the first round since they took Gabe Carimi 29<sup>th</sup> overall 15 years ago. GM Ryan Poles and coach Ben Johnson could still find a Day 1 starter on either side of the line at No. 25, Jeremiah said — and don't need to swing a trade to do it.</p><p></p><p>“They’re in a good spot,” he said.</p><p></p><p>With Ozzy Trapilo expected to need until at least midseason to recover from a patellar tendon injury and Braxton Jones about to become a free agent, the Bears are in the market for a starting left tackle, be it via trade, free agency or the draft. The Bears will continue to get a sense of the market when they attend the NFL Scouting Combine next week in Indianapolis.</p><p></p><p>Left tackles who could be available at No. 25 include Clemson’s Blake Miller, Georgia’s Monroe Freeling, Alabama’s Kadyn Proctor and Utah’s Caleb Lomu. Arizona State’s Max Iheanachor could climb up to that spot, too. The 6-5, 325 pounder moved to Los Angeles area from Nigeria in middle school and didn’t play football until junior college. Jeremiah ranked him No. 41 overall before he dominated during Senior Bowl week.</p><p></p><p>“He’s a big, physical dude whose best football is ahead of him,” Jeremiah said. “He could start getting ahead, into that range of the draft as well. Out of that clump, I can’t envision all of them would be gone, so you’re going to get one of those guys that would be able to be plug-and-play.”</p><p></p><p>Fano and Freeling are ranked No. 19 and 21, respectively, on ESPN analyst Mel Kiper Jr.’s list of top 25 draftable players.</p><p></p><p>At defensive end, the Bears could eye Miami’s Akheem Mesidor, who will be 25 when the season starts, or Auburn’s Keldric Faulk, who doesn’t turn 21 until September.</p><p></p><p>Faulk has an ideal body type and moves smoothly, Jeremiah said, but hasn’t shown the pass-rish production that teams want. Teams are “all over the map” about where he could get picked, Jeremiah said. Mesidor, who was born in Ottawa, has the ability to rush from wide but also from the inside when he moves to tackle.</p><p></p><p>“It’s just not fair with him against college guards — he just kills them in there …” Jeremiah said. “This guy never stops. There’s never a breath you can take when you’re trying to block Akheem Mesidor.”</p><p></p><p>At 6-3, Mesidor might be too short for Dennis Allen’s scheme. The same can be said for Texas A&M’s Cashius Howell, who is 6-2 and, Jeremiah said, has shorter-than-ideal arms. Still, he could run a blazing 40-yard dash next week. Clemson’s T.J. Parker, Oklahoma’s R. Mason Thomas and Missouri’s Zion Young could be available when the Bears pick 25th.</p><p></p><p>Jeremiah put Clemson defensive tackle Peter Woods on the Bears in his latest mock draft, praising his pass-rush ability. The Bears could turn to a standout safety class with their first pick, too, he said.</p><p></p><p>“They’re well-positioned for where they area,” he said.</p><p></p><p>The only sure thing in this year’s draft appears to be the fact the Raiders will take Indiana quarterback Fernando Mendoza first overall. Jeremiah said he didn’t grade Mendoza as high as the Bears’ Caleb Williams, Patriots’ Drake Maye or Commanders’ Jayden Daniels when they left college two years ago.</p><p></p><p>“He would slot in behind those guys,” he said. “But I think he’s excellent.”<br></p>
entries.author: Patrick Finley

entries.title: Neglected storybook house in Beverly heads toward a happy ending, thanks to $1.5 million state grant
entries.summary: <p>The Eugene S. Pike House is storybook perfect: a quaint, wood and stone 19th century Tudor Revival home on the edge of a forest preserve.</p><p>But its story had been one of neglect in recent decades.</p><p>The Forest Preserve District of Cook County owns the home, near 91st Street and Longwood Drive, at the southern tip of 257-acre Dan Ryan Woods. But it lacked the cash keep it in good repair — or even fix up the house when its condition slipped.</p><p>However, the 132-year-old Beverly landmark might end up happily ever after, as the first phase of stabilization and repairs on the vacant building is likely to begin this spring following a $1.5 million state grant.</p><p>The funding was set aside in 2024 but wasn't able to be allocated until last month. That's when the Cook County Board approved a partnership agreement with the recently-created Eugene S. Pike House Foundation and the Beverly Area Arts Alliance that allows the groups to raise money for the home's rehabilitation and ultimately, use the building as the Pike House Community Cultural Center.</p><p>"There's a lot of us out here who really care deeply about preserving any historic property that can be preserved," Eugene S. Pike House Foundation President Grace Kuikman said. "But the Pike House — it's just special."</p><h3>Once upon a time</h3><p>The Eugene S. Pike House was built in 1894 as a gardener's cottage on what were then the grounds of Pike's 32-acre estate. </p><p>Pike, a real estate developer who helped downtown rebuild after the Great Chicago Fire of 1872, hired architect Henry Hale Waterman to design the small home. </p><p>Waterman's solution was perfect for the site: a picturesque home with a deep-pitched gable roof, rusticated sandstone base, half-timbering and prominent turret.</p><p>The American Institute of Architects Guide to Chicago said the house looks as if one could "expect Hansel and Gretel to come tripping past."</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-220000" name="image-220000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f917bd2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5541x3110+0+485/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe0%2F3d%2F79f533c44987821d7012fdc2cbf8%2Fimg-0922.jpeg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="An early photo of the H.H. Waterman-designed Eugene S. Pike House taken before an addition — designed by Waterman — was built." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f917bd2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5541x3110+0+485/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe0%2F3d%2F79f533c44987821d7012fdc2cbf8%2Fimg-0922.jpeg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0522abe/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5541x3110+0+485/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe0%2F3d%2F79f533c44987821d7012fdc2cbf8%2Fimg-0922.jpeg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f917bd2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5541x3110+0+485/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe0%2F3d%2F79f533c44987821d7012fdc2cbf8%2Fimg-0922.jpeg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>An early photo of the H.H. Waterman-designed Eugene S. Pike House taken before an addition — designed by Waterman — was built.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided by Eugene S. Pike House Foundation/Tim Samuelson</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Waterman was just 25 years old and had made his bones as a draftsman, working in the downtown office of Joseph Lyman Silsbee, the architect whose firm had its share of giants on the rise, including Frank Lloyd Wright and George W. Maher.</p><p>In addition to the Pike House, Waterman designed at least 40 other structures in the Beverly and Morgan Park communities from the 1890s to the 1920s, including what was briefly his own home at 10838 S. Longwood Drive, which was built into the glacial ridge along Longwood Drive that marks the two neighborhoods. (A non-Beverly/Morgan Park Waterman design I've always liked is <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/architecture-design/2025/06/19/endangered-washington-park-building-frank-lloyd-wright-rescue" target="_blank" >South Park Terrace</a> at 61st and King Drive.)</p><p>Ridge Historical Society Director Tim Blackburn said most of Waterman's Beverly and Morgan Park work sits on or near the ridge.</p><p>"He just built so many houses and really used the ridge and the majestic hill [created by it] to its fullest effect," Blackburn said.</p><p>The Forest Preserve District bought Pike's estate in 1921, when the agency moved to create Dan Ryan Woods. The home was used as the Forest Preserve District superintendent's office then became the Dan Ryan Woods watchman's house in the 1960s.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-d60000" name="image-d60000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0b44e5b/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+172/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2Fbe%2F5defa6e24cbb8287e596ac8d5349%2Fpike-260209-14.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0000987/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+172/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2Fbe%2F5defa6e24cbb8287e596ac8d5349%2Fpike-260209-14.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6f6489c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+172/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2Fbe%2F5defa6e24cbb8287e596ac8d5349%2Fpike-260209-14.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Behind the Eugene S. Pike House in Beverly" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6f6489c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+172/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2Fbe%2F5defa6e24cbb8287e596ac8d5349%2Fpike-260209-14.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4725e97/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+172/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2Fbe%2F5defa6e24cbb8287e596ac8d5349%2Fpike-260209-14.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6f6489c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+172/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2Fbe%2F5defa6e24cbb8287e596ac8d5349%2Fpike-260209-14.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>The backyard area of the Eugene S. Pike House in Beverly.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Tyler Pasciak LaRiviere/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3>More repair money needed</h3><p>The $1.5 million grant will cover exterior repairs, Kuikman said. The home was in such bad condition that Landmarks Illinois listed it among the state's most endangered places in 2022.</p><p>"The roof is in terrible condition, and there's a lot of structural things that need to be replaced and saved and rehabilitated," she said. "Foundation issues need to be addressed in phase one [and the] beautiful red sandstone exterior that was common with those Waterman houses of that time."</p><p>Cook County Commissioner Stanley Moore helped the home get funding. Legislation for the grant was sponsored by State Sen. Willie Preston (16th).</p><p>While Kuikman said repair work will begin in the spring, another $1.5 million or so will be needed down the road to repair the home's interior.</p><p>"The interior is in pretty sad shape," she said.</p><p>When the work is done, the home will be an asset to the area, Beverly Area Arts Alliance President Sal Campbell said.</p><p>The group will have discussions with the community about the building's future use, she said. But the organization envisions the home hosting exhibitions, classes and an artist-in-residence program that could feature "artists from all over the world to stay there and share their art," Campbell said.</p><p>"We want to draw people to that place," she said.</p>
entries.author: Lee Bey

entries.title: Jesse Jackson’s vision for America embraced environmental justice
entries.summary: <p>Peggy Shepard walked into her living room on Tuesday morning when her husband told her Jesse Jackson, the civil rights titan from South Carolina, had died. “Immediately tears started coming,” said Shepard, co-founder and executive director of WE ACT for Environmental Justice, a New York City-based nonprofit.</p><p>Nearly 40 years ago, Jackson had altered the course of Shepard’s life. In the late 1980s, she was working as an editor at Time-Life Books, when a colleague mentioned an organizing meeting for Jackson’s 1988 presidential campaign in Manhattan’s Greenwich Village. “I walked into this Saturday meeting, and I walked out on air,” Shepard recalled. “Two hours later, I'm the press secretary for the Jackson campaign in Manhattan.”</p><p>That campaign — which would prove groundbreaking for Shepard and the country — pushed issues that had rarely been centered in national politics. Jackson made environmental justice, a term Americans were largely unfamiliar with at the time, a key plank of his second presidential run. He called for a national energy policy that would make offshore oil drilling obsolete, a plan to phase out nuclear energy, measures to reduce tailpipe pollution from cars, a conservation strategy to restore the nation's wetlands and forests, and a federally sponsored workforce in the style of the New Deal Civilian Conservation Corps. (The Biden administration launched a similar program, the American Climate Corps, in 2024, but <a class="Link" href="https://grist.org/politics/american-climate-corps-biden-jobs-program-trump/" target="_blank" ><u>shuttered</u></a> it days ahead of President Trump’s return to office last year.)</p><p>“Being in the Jesse Jackson campaign led to everything I'm doing right now,” said Shepard of the volunteer job that took her across New York City and exposed her to stark disparities between neighborhoods, especially in pollution burdens. “If I hadn't gone to that Saturday meeting, I'm not sure that I'd be sitting here today in this position.”</p><p>Jackson marched with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., transformed American politics with his two historic presidential campaigns, and inspired countless organizers — including environmental justice advocates — along the way. In his later years, he began making connections between segregation in Greenville, South Carolina, where he was born, and the toxic drinking water in Flint, Michigan.</p><h3></h3><h3>Inspiring environmental justice advocacy in Chicago</h3><p>Cheryl Johnson, who runs the Chicago-based environmental justice nonprofit People for Community Recovery, was about 10 years old when she first saw Jackson in person. It was a grade-school field trip to the Rainbow PUSH Coalition, the prominent civil rights nonprofit he founded in 1971, headquartered on the South Side. The towering figure left a lifelong impression on her.</p><p>“I always remember he would say, ‘up with hope, down with dope,’” she said, recalling Jackson’s stockpile of charismatic appeals. “To see him fighting, at that particular time, for the right to be black in America, was an inspiration for me that I followed for many, many years,” Johnson said.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/columnists/2026/02/18/lights-camera-jesse-jackson-civil-rights-leader-pop-culture-presence" >Lights, camera, Jackson: Civil Rights leader also became a pop culture presence</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>From the television set to magazine covers, Johnson grew up with Jackson in the background. Her mother, Hazel Johnson, founded People for Community Recovery, one of the first environmental justice organizations in the country, and worked with Jackson several times during the Clinton administration. Today Hazel Johnson is remembered as “the mother of the environmental justice movement.” Cheryl Johnson never worked directly with Jackson on environmental issues in Chicago, but the two "would have discussions on the phone," she said. "He got it."</p><p>Jackson was often pragmatic, not allowing environmental concerns to outweigh what he believed Black communities needed. In 2021, he successfully urged Illinois lawmakers to propose legislation making it easier to build a natural gas pipeline to the rural Pembroke Township south of Chicago, once referred to as the largest Black farming community in the Northern U.S.</p><p>“A secure source of energy would help kickstart other development — and in turn create jobs and generate hope,” Jackson wrote in an op-ed in support of the plan. As of this year, the pipeline is delivering <a class="Link" href="https://www.shawlocal.com/daily-journal/2026/01/15/economic-alliance/" target="_blank" ><u>natural gas to over 100 residents</u></a>.</p><p>Jackson also took an active interest in the Flint water crisis, showing up repeatedly and lending support. In early 2016, Melissa Mays filed a lawsuit against the city of Flint, Michigan, for exposing nearly 100,000 residents to unsafe water contaminated with lead, a toxic metal linked to developmental delays, cardiovascular issues, and infertility.</p><p>Mays, a longtime Flint resident and a then-emerging clean water activist, remembers sitting in front of cameras and answering questions about her lawsuit when, unexpectedly, Jackson walked through the doors. “He walks right up to us to ask if he can say something,” she said.</p><p>Not long after, Jackson declared that officials should put “tape around the city, because Flint is a crime scene." Mays said the moment validated her concerns and in part kicked off a longtime friendship between the two. Jackson returned to Flint repeatedly, helping turn the water crisis into national news and criticizing the Obama administration for not sufficiently responding to the crisis. He made his last public appearance in Flint in 2024 to visit the Flint Southwestern Classical Academy to highlight the importance of voting.</p><p>“He was not afraid of anybody,” Mays said.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago/2026/02/17/what-we-know-rev-jesse-jacksons-death-services" >What we know about Rev. Jesse Jackson’s death and plans to honor his life in Chicago</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Juanpablo Ramirez-Franco | WBEZ

entries.title: Arrest made in deadly Lake View, Bronzeville carjackings: source
entries.summary: <p>An arrest has been made in the slayings of two men that happened an hour apart during linked carjackings earlier this month in <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/lakeview" >Lake View</a> and Bronzeville, according to a source. </p><p>No charges have been announced for the person held, an 18-year-old South Side man, the source told the Chicago Sun-Times.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2026/02/12/murderslinked" target="_blank" >Darwin Tirado, 22, and Damon Kellum, 45, were killed about an hour apart in the Feb. 11 attacks</a>, according to the Cook County medical examiner’s office and police.</p><p>Tirado was in them 700 block of West Waveland Avenue, sitting in a parked car,having a conversation with a 38-year-old man after the two had departed a nearby tavern when two people attacked them, killing Tirado and fleeing in his car, according to police reports. The 38-year-old was not injured. </p><p>About an an hour later and 12 miles away in <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bronzeville" >Bronzeville,</a> Kellum was gunned down in the 3700 block of South Lake Park Avenue and the Tirado’s car was found nearby, according to police, who said the two assailants tried at least twice more to carjack vehicles after the killings on the same day, police said. </p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2021/12/31/22848890/chicago-carjackings-inside-mind-chicago-carjacker" >Inside the mind of a Chicago carjacker</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/06/06/kid-carjackers-srt-boys-carjackings-burglaries-north-lawndale-juvenile-crime" >Chicago’s kid carjackers: Inside the SRT Boys’ yearslong crime spree</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire
